channel.title: Stepper motor infomation
channel.description:
I just found a box of stepper motors, they all seem to be similar. Ill get pics but here is what is written on them:
SET A: 42SIM-24D6YA1 7.5DEG 12OHM
SET B: 42SIM-24DCYA1 7.5DEG 36OHM
They all have a date format of:
DDMMMYYXX
eg
06JUL91TA, XX is two letters.
It would be great if anyone could find some information on them, eg datasheets. Cheers in advance!

item.title: Stepper motor infomation
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

You’re best to just sell them and buy some steppers from Sparkfun or somewhere.

I started a CNC project about a year ago but gave-up soon after due to lack of commitment and funds.

EDIT: Sorry about the gravedig, didn’t notice the date. Also, there was no reply from the author, so I gather the discussion’s still “active”.

Read full topic

item.title: Stepper motor infomation
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

I recently took a stepper motor out of a printer, by applying +24v and 0v to ab and cd in sequence I could make it spin slowly round (using a series resistor to limit the current of course), just do tests like that and you should find out how it works, they generally all work the same though.

Read full topic

item.title: Stepper motor infomation
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Unhandled:

Put some voltage in and see what happens???

you have to put pulses to the coils, there are 4 coils and one common.

Read full topic
